This project is a subset of a project headed by

In addition to Dr. Sterling, Rosie Wollander was immensely helpful in collecting data for all of the experiments. Thank you both for all of your help!

<div class="box">
<span style="font-size: 30px;"><strong> Project Overview </strong></span>  
Astragalus and Oxytropix species, part of the Legume Family, are found in terrestrial ecosystems globally, including the western regions of North America. Many of these species are both nontoxic and important forages. However, several species are known to be toxic to both livestock and wildlife. *Oxytropis sericea Nutt* can harbor a commensal endophyte, *Alternaira oxytropos*, a fungus that is associated with locoweed plants, specifically those of the genus *Oxytropis*. Plants containing the endophyte have been found to produce swansonine, a toxic alkaloid that can be harmful to livestock when ingested in large quantities. In this study, we investigated the differences in volatile organic compound (VOC) emissions between both field and greenhouse specimens that contained the commensal endophyte *Alternaria oxytropis*, and those that did not (E+/E-).

</div>
